_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Bama Companies, Inc. - Bama Pie facility abides by the emergency response procedures and policies detailed in the Bama Safety Plan manual.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1)    To save lives.

2)    To minimize and avoid injuries.

3)    To protect the environment.

4)    To minimize property damage.



Bama Pie maintains an emergency response team whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the OSHA PSM Standard and the EPA RMP Rule, as well as to incorporate any changes to the facility, personnel, roles and responsibilities, procedures, etc. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Bama Pie facility prepares frozen bakery products for distribution.  The facility utilizes an industrial refrigeration system in order to conduct operations, and ammonia is used in the system as a refrigerant.  Prior to December 2003, the facility operated a small refrigeration system that was not applicable to the EPA RMP regulation.  The facility underwent a major expansion, and operations on the newly expanded system began in December 2003.  As a result of the expansion, the facility is required to comply with Program Level 3 of the EPA RMP Rule.



The refrigeration process, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide cooling for process equipment and cold storage rooms. Typical operating conditions range from vacuum (approximately 15.5" Hg) on the

low pressure side of the system to 150-160 psig on the high side.



The total ammonia inventory is 37,000 pounds.



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

In order to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system, Bama Pie has developed an accidental release prevention program that complies with the following regulations:



1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard; and

2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.



The program is comprised of several elements geared towards the prevention of an accidental release of ammonia and ensuring the safety of employees and the surrounding community.



In addition to implementing the program, Bama Pie follows recognized standards and good engineering practices using state and local codes and IIAR standards for operating and maintaining the ammonia refrigeration system.  The system has been designed with several safety features to prevent a release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed at key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  Ammonia sensors are installed throughout the facility which will alert plant personnel in the event of an ammonia detection.



Five Year Accident History

A review of the Bama Pie's five year accident history (December 2013 - December 2018) showed that there have been no incidents at the facility that meet the RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds.



Within the course of the last five

years, the facility has experienced small ammonia leaks from the system, however none of these incidents meet the criteria discussed above.  As required, these incidents are investigated following the procedures within the Incident Investigation program.  The objective of the investigation is to determine the root cause of the leak and any contributing factors, and to devise and implement corrective actions to prevent recurrence of these incidents.



Emergency Response Program

Bama Pie has an Emergency Response Program, which includes procedures for responding to ammonia releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite.  The facility has an Emergency Response Team that is trained to the Hazmat Technician Level.  Emergency response team members receive initial 24-hour training and an 8-hour refresher on an annual basis.  Incident Commanders also receive 8-hour initial training and 8-hour annual refresher training.  Emergency Response Team members who are trained in hazardous materials management and decontamination are fit tested and respiratory trained annually.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Bama Pie has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe work environment.  The most recent Compliance Audit was completed on March 16, 2017. The Process Hazard Analysis was recently updated on September 27, 2018 to address the addition of a new spiral freezer per MOC Record No. BP-41. Recommendations were generated as a result of these analyses to improve safety at the facility.
